original_title: Bronx: Pelham Parkway South - Sacket Avenue
text:
Morris Park Race Track: A general view northeastward as seen from the grand stand. The track was bound on the north by Pelham Parkway South; on the south by Sackett Avenue; on the east by Williamsbridge Road; on the west by Barnes and Bronxdale Avenues. The entire race track property was offered for sale to the general public in June 1913, after streets and plots were marked out by Joseph P. Day and J. Clarence Davies. For additional data see the New York Times of April 27, June 15, and June 22, 1913.
About 1910

(2)
A fashionable gathering at Morris Park Race Track.
About 1910

original_title: Bronx: Pelham Parkway South - Sacket Avenue
text:
Morris Park Race Track: A general view northeastward as seen from the grand stand. The track was bound on the north by Pelham Parkway South; on the south by Sackett Avenue; on the east by Williamsbridge Road; on the west by Barnes and Bronxdale Avenues. The entire race track property was offered for sale to the general public in June 1913, after streets and plots were marked out by Joseph P. Day and J. Clarence Davies. For additional data see the New York Times of April 27, June 15, and June 22, 1913.
About 1910

original_title: Bronx: Pelham Parkway South - Sacket Avenue
text:
Morris Park Race Track (Bronx): Viewing north across the fashionable track from near the grand stand. The track was bounded on the east by Williamsbridge Road; on the west by Barnes Avenue; on the north by Pelham Parkway; and on the south by Sackett Avenue. In June, 1913 "the most remarkable real estate sale in the history of the city", as the New York Times commented editorially, took place when the track property was offered for auction by Joseph P. Day and Clarence Davies. For additional data see "The New York Times," April 27, June 15, and June 22, 1913.

About 1910?
Views 1,2:
Probably earlier.

original_title: Bronx: Pelham Parkway South - Sacket Avenue

Morris Park Race Track (Bronx): Viewing north across the fashionable track from near the grand stand. The track was bounded on the east by Williamsbridge Road; on the west by Barnes Avenue; on the north by Pelham Parkway; and on the south by Sackett Avenue. In June, 1913 "the most remarkable real estate sale in the history of the city", as the New York Times commented editorially, took place when the track property was offered for auction by Joseph P. Day and Clarence Davies. For additional data see "The New York Times," April 27, June 15, and June 22, 1913.

About 1910?
Views 1,2:
Probably earlier.

Bronx and Pelham Parkway, east from Williamsbridge Road, showing (right) part of the Pearsall estate.

Summer 1914.

W. D. Hassler.
title: Bronx: Bronx and Pelham Par - Williamsbridge Road

text:
Bronx and Pelham Parkway, east from but not including Williamsbridge Road, showing, on the south side of the Parkway (right), part of the extensive Pearsall estate.

Spring 1914.

W. D. Hassler.
title: Bronx: Bronx and Pelham Par - Market Street

text:
Bronx and pelham Parkway, east from Williamsbridge Road, showing part of the Pearsall Estate offered for sale. It is situated on the south side of the Parkway, east of Williamsbridge Road. It adjoined the famous Morris Park Race Track which was sold in June of 1913.

1914.
title: Bronx: Bronx and Pelham Par - Williamsbridge Road

original_title: Bronx: Williamsbridge Road - Pelham Parkway South
text:
Williamsbridge Road, south from Pelham Parkway South. The land on the east side of the road (left) is part of the extensive Pearsall estate.

1914.

Bronx and Pelham Parkway, west from Williamsbridge Road. The hand-sign with the inscription Woodmansten Inn, points to the famous inn situated at the N.W. corner of Williamsbridge Road and Van Nest Aves. It was a familiar gathering place for visitors to the Morris Park Race Track, which it adjoined.

About 1923.
title: Bronx: Bronx and Pelham Par - Williamsbridge Road

original_title: Bronx: Williamsbridge Road - Pelham Parkway South
text:
Williamsbridge Road, south from Pelham Parkway South.
January 26, 1937
W.P.A. Photo
Five Boroughs Project
